data.title: Surname Rawlings: Meaning Origin Variants
data.meta_description: What does the surname Rawlings mean? Where does it come from and what are the variants of Rawlings? Which famous people have the surname Rawlings?
data.text:
Rawlings: What does the surname Rawlings mean?

The surname Rawlings is of English origin and it is a patronymic form of the personal name Rawlin. The name Rawlin is derived from a medieval variant of the given name Roland, which itself is of Old Germanic origin and combined the elements "hrod", meaning "renown", and "landa", meaning "land". So, Rawlings can be interpreted as 'son of Rawlin' or 'son of Roland'. This name was popular among the Normans due to the famous medieval epic poem, 'Chanson de Roland'. The surname Rawlings is first recorded in the late 12th Century in England. The surname has many variations including Rawlings, Rawlins, Rawlinson and Rollings among others.

Order DNA origin analysis

Rawlings: Where does the name Rawlings come from?

The last name Rawlings is most commonly found in the United Kingdom and the United States today. In the UK, records from the 1881 census reveal that the name was most common in Devon and Cornwall in the southwest of England and in counties such as Berkshire, Gloucestershire, and Warwickshire in the midlands.

In the United States, the name Rawlings is most common in the South and Midwest regions, with the highest concentrations in Arkansas, Missouri, and Texas. There are also pockets of people with the last name in states like Florida, Georgia, North Carolina, and Virginia.

Today, Rawlings is a popular last name across the world due to its English origins. It has not only been established in the UK and the US, but can also be found in countries such as Canada, Australia, and New Zealand.

Although the name is more widely used in English-speaking countries, it has also made its way to other parts of the world. In countries like Chile, Mexico, and South Africa, people with the last name Rawlings have made their presence felt by contributing to the local cultures.

Variations of the surname Rawlings

Rawlings is an English surname derived from the personal name “Rawlin” which is thought to be a diminutive for an Old German name, Rudolph. It is also a variant spelling of the more common Rawlinson. The spelling variants of Rawlings may include Rawlins, Rawlinson, Rawlison, Rowlinson and Rolinson.

The Rawlings surname is relatively widespread with a few common variants. It is primarily located in England, specifically in Hertfordshire and Gloucestershire. However there are some Mainland European families named Rauschlings and Rauslings. Both of which are linguistically similar to the English surname “Rawlings”.

Other surnames of the same origin are Rauschinger and Rausing which are both derived from the Germanic language. Additionally there is the surname Rawles which is thought to be derived from a nickname of the personal name Ralph. It is quite uncommon but can still be found in certain parts of England.

Rawlings is also closely related to the more common surnames Rollins, Rollings, and Rolinson. It is quite common amongst English speaking countries, and has been found in both the US and Canada. As such, many people of the Rawlings surname can trace their ancestry to Northwest Europe.

Overall, Rawlings is a relatively widespread surname with a few variants. It is primarily found in England, but can also be found in other parts of Northwest Europe. It is closely related to surnames Rollins, Rollings, Rawles, Rauschinger, Rausing and Rolinson.
